If I deal with him without restraint, he will endanger our state." Xuan comments: "If one indulges his transgressions, he will surely overthrow the nation." "If I deal with him with restraint, he will endanger my person." "If I regulate him with laws and standards, he will first harm me."

"His knowledge suffices only to recognize others’ faults but not the cause of those faults." As the *Shi Wen* notes: "His knowledge, pronounced as *zhi*." He only knows how to blame others, not his own errors.

"In such a case, what am I to do?"

Qu Boyu said, "Excellent question! Be vigilant, be cautious—first rectify yourself! First seek to be without fault yourself.

In form, nothing is better than closeness; in mind, nothing is better than harmony." Xuan comments: "Outwardly, show the form of intimate attachment; inwardly, harbor the intent of harmonious compliance."

"Yet even these two have their dangers." Xuan comments: "They are still not perfectly good."

Closeness must not become intrusion; harmony must not become overt. Attachment must not run too deep, lest one fail to guard against his excesses; compliance must not be too apparent, lest one fail to guide his tendencies.

If form becomes too close and intrusive, it will lead to collapse, ruin, destruction, and downfall. Collapse means falling; ruin means annihilation; destruction means breaking; downfall means stumbling.

If the mind becomes too harmonious and overt, it will lead to reputation, fame, misfortune, and calamity. Guo comments: "If one displays harmony, it will give rise to a reputation for bearing disgrace; if one aids his fame, he will resent being surpassed and falsely generate misfortune and calamity."

If he acts like a child, then act like a child with him—this is a metaphor for lacking discernment.

If he acts without boundaries, then act without boundaries with him—this is a metaphor for minor transgressions.

If he acts without limits, then act without limits with him—this means not establishing rigid barriers.

Understand him, and enter into flawlessness. Follow his intentions to comprehend them, and thereby enter into a state without blemish.

Do you not know the mantis? It brandished its arms to block the wheel tracks of a chariot, unaware that it was unequal to the task—such was the beauty of its talent.

Do you not know those who raise tigers? They dare not feed them living creatures, for fear of provoking their killing rage; they dare not feed them whole creatures, for fear of provoking their tearing rage. Thus, those they kill are those who oppose them. If a tiger opposes, it kills; if it is fed, it fawns. This is a metaphor for how one must not provoke anger. This is another analogy.

Those who love horses gather their dung in baskets and collect their urine in conches—so says Cheng: "Conches are large clamshells." This is the utmost in loving horses. Yet when horseflies or gadflies alight upon them (Wang Niansun notes: "The character 仆 here means 'to attach.' The phrase describes flies clinging to the horse's body. The *Book of Songs* says, 'The illustrious mandate has its attachments,' and Mao's commentary explains: 'Attachments are what cling.'"), and one pats them at the wrong moment (Cheng explains: "拊 means to slap. 不时 means catching the horse unawares"), the horse may break its bit, shatter its bridle, or smash its chest. The horse is startled to this degree. When one’s intentions are carried to an extreme, love may turn to loss—how can one not be cautious? This is a third analogy.

A carpenter named Shi traveled to Qi and arrived at Qu Yuan, where he saw a sacred oak used as the village shrine. (Shi is the carpenter’s name. 之 means "to go." Sima explains: "Qu Yuan is a winding road." Cheng comments: "Like the road of Huanyuan." 社 refers to the earth deity; the oak is the sacred tree of the shrine.) The tree was so vast it could shade thousands of oxen, its girth measured in a hundred spans (the *Wen Xuan* commentary cites Sima: "絜 means 'to encircle.'"), and Li explains: "A span is the width of one hand; this tree was likely ten *zhang* in circumference." Its height towered above the mountain by ten *ren* before branches appeared, and its side limbs that could be made into boats numbered nearly ten. (Yu notes: "旁 and 方 were interchangeable in ancient times. 方 means 'nearly.' Thus, the limbs suitable for boats numbered nearly ten.") Spectators gathered like a marketplace, yet the master carpenter paid no heed and walked on without pause. (遂 means "to proceed." The *Wen Xuan* commentary cites Sima: "Shi was the carpenter’s courtesy name.") His disciple, sated with the sight, ran to catch up with the carpenter and said: "Since I first took up the axe to follow you, master, I have never seen timber so magnificent. Why do you refuse to look and walk on without stopping?"

The carpenter replied: "Enough! Say no more! It is a useless tree. If made into a boat, it would sink; its weight is too great. If made into a coffin or outer coffin, it would rot quickly; its grain is too coarse. If made into vessels, they would break at once; its wood is too brittle. If used for doors or gates, it would ooze resin (Li Zhen notes: "The *Guangyun* defines 樠 as 'the heartwood of pine' or the name of a tree. Pine heartwood contains sap, and 液樠 refers to this property."). If used for pillars, it would be eaten by worms. It is a worthless tree, good for nothing—this has been discussed in earlier chapters such as the *Free and Easy Wandering*. That is why it has lived so long."

When the carpenter returned home, the sacred oak appeared to him in a dream and said: "With what would you compare me? Would you liken me to the so-called 'patterned wood'?" (Guo explains: "Patterned wood refers to all usable timber, which can be carved into designs.") "Consider the crabapple, pear, orange, pomelo, and other fruit-bearing trees (Cheng comments: "蓏 refers to melons and gourds."). When their fruit ripens, they are stripped and humiliated; their great branches are broken, and their small branches are dragged away (Yu notes: "泄 should be read as 曳. In the *Xunzi*'s *Fei Xiang* chapter, 'When meeting people, one uses dragging,' and Yang's commentary explains: 'Dragging means to pull.' 小枝泄 refers to branches being pulled."). This is because their usefulness brings suffering to their lives, so they do not complete their natural lifespan but die prematurely—struck down by the world’s conventions through their own actions (Cheng comments: "掊 means to strike."). All things are like this. As for me, I have sought to be of no use for a long time; I nearly died, nearly felled to my death. Only now have I attained this state (Guo explains: "Many have looked at me with disdain, but only now has the carpenter understood me."), which is of great use to me. If I had been useful, would I have grown so vast? Moreover, you and I are both things—how could you judge me as a thing? You, a nearly dead, worthless man, what could you know of a worthless tree?" (而 here means "you." 几 means "nearly.")

They time their hunger and satiety and understand their angry impulses. Tigers, though of a different species from humans, fawn upon those who feed them—this is compliance. Thus, those they kill are those who oppose them. If a tiger opposes, it kills; if it is fed, it fawns. This is a metaphor for how one must not provoke anger. This is another analogy.

The carpenter Shi awoke and interpreted his dream. Wang Niansun notes: "‘Diagnosed’ (*zhěn*) should be read as *zhěn* (告, ‘to inform’)." He informed his disciples of the dream. A disciple asked: "If you hasten to seek uselessness, then why serve as a shrine tree?" Since you urgently pursue uselessness to preserve your life, why must you become a shrine tree to adorn yourself?

He replied: "Hush!" (This means "keep it secret." Yao Nai notes: "密 and 默 are interchangeable. In the *Tian Zifang* chapter, Confucius says: ‘Silence! Say no more!’ In the *Dasheng* chapter, it reads: ‘The Duke kept it secret and did not respond.’") Say no more! That tree merely lodges there, enduring the scorn and reproach of those who do not understand it. It merely dwells by the shrine, bearing the slander of those who fail to know it without complaint. Sima Biao comments: "厉 means ‘affliction.’"

If it were not a shrine tree, it would nearly have been felled! If it were not a shrine tree, it would almost have been cut down—perhaps split into firewood. Moreover, what it preserves differs from the multitude. It is safeguarded in the mountains and wilds, ultimately distinct from the common crowd, not to be likened to a city fox or shrine rat. To praise it by conventional standards—is this not far off the mark? Xuan comments: "义 means ‘common principle.’" The point is: that tree does not rely on the shrine spirit for self-glorification, so to commend it by conventional reasoning is far from its true nature.

Cui comments: "隐 means ‘afflicted by heat.’" Cheng explains: "A team of four horses is called a *cheng*. This says that a thousand chariots could gather, finding shelter from the heat in its shade." Ziqi said: "This tree is truly a worthless wood, and yet it has grown to such immense size!" The insight moves from wood to man. Xuan comments: "The spirit-like person likewise, by not displaying his talents, remains useless to the world, and thus Heaven alone preserves him whole."

In Song there was a region called Jing, where catalpa, cypress, and mulberry flourished. Of these trees, those with trunks the size of a man’s embrace or smaller were felled by those seeking pegs for monkeys; Sima explains: "A trunk held by two hands is called *gong*; by one hand, *ba*." Xuan notes: "*Yi* are tethering stakes." Those three or four spans in girth were cut down by those seeking fine timber for grand beams; Cui states: "Eight feet make one span." Guo Qingfan observes: "Here *ming* means ‘large’" (see *Under Heaven*, under "three hundred famous mountains"). Cheng comments: "*Li* refers to roof beams." Those seven or eight spans in girth were hewn by the households of nobles and wealthy merchants seeking single-plank coffin sides. *Shiwen* notes: "*Shan* is also written as *tan*." Cheng explains: "A coffin side made from a single unjoined plank is called *shanpang*. Such trees are enormous, requiring the cutting of vast boards." Thus, before completing their natural lifespan, they were prematurely felled by axes—this is the calamity of usefulness.

Therefore, when exorcists perform purifications, they reject oxen with white foreheads, pigs with upturned snouts, and men with hemorrhoids, deeming them unfit for sacrifice in the sacred river. Guo explains: "*Jie* refers to the exorcism rites of shamans." Cheng comments: "*Sang* is the forehead. *Kang* means ‘raised.’ These three cannot be taken to the numinous river for sacrifice." In ancient times, men were drowned in the river as offerings—when Ximen Bao served as magistrate of Ye, he put an end to this practice, which was of this kind. The shamans knew this well. *Yi* and *yi* are interchangeable. Guo notes: "Even the shamans understood that the useless remain whole." What is deemed inauspicious is precisely what the spirit-like person regards as the greatest auspice. Xuan comments: "To preserve one’s life whole—what greater blessing could there be?" (In one edition, the character *er* appears above *yi*.)

There was a man named Zhili Shu, whose body was deformed. Sima describes: "Zhili depicts a form that is incomplete. *Shu* is his name." His chin rested on his navel, his shoulders rose above his head; Sima explains: "This describes a hunched back and a sunken head." *Huainanzi* states: "His spinal column towered above his head." His topknot pointed to the sky; Sima comments: "The *huicu* is a topknot. In ancient times, topknots were worn at the nape, but with a hunched back and lowered head, the topknot would point upward." Cui says: "*Huicu* refers to the cervical vertebrae." Li Zhen argues: "Cui’s interpretation is correct. In the *Great and Venerable Master* chapter, it says: ‘*Gouzui* points to the sky.’ Li explains: ‘*Gouzui* are the cervical vertebrae, resembling a growth.’ This aligns with Cui’s view. The *Suwen*’s *Cire* chapter states: ‘The third vertebra of the neck, where it is sunken, is the center.’ Wang’s commentary: ‘This outlines the general method for counting vertebrae.’ Shen Tong’s *Explanation of Bones* says: ‘The twenty-one vertebrae below the great cervical vertebra are collectively called the spine, and the bones are called vertebrae.’ The *Nanjing*’s forty-fifth difficulty states: ‘The bones gather at *dazhu*.’ Zhang’s commentary: ‘*Dazhu* is an acupoint located at the first vertebra behind the neck. From here, all bones branch downward like a framework, hence the bones gather at *dazhu*.’ *Huicu* derives its meaning from the gathering of bones and is situated among the cervical vertebrae, hence it is called the ‘cervical vertebra.’ *Chu Xue Ji* 19 cites *cuo* as written as *cuo*. The *Yupian* states: ‘*Cuo* is a knot in wood,’ which resembles a spinal node. The character written with the wood radical is more appropriate in meaning." The five *guan* were on his upper back; Li explains: "*Guan* are the *shu* points. The *shu* points of the five viscera are all located on a person’s back." Li Zhen comments: "The chin and shoulders describe external features; the *huicu* and five *guan* describe internal ones." His thighs aligned with his ribs. Sima explains: "With a hunched spine and raised belly, his thighs pressed against his ribs." He mended clothes and washed laundry, enough to feed himself; Sima notes: "*Cuo zhen* means sewing. *Xie* means washing clothes." He sifted grain and winnowed chaff, enough to feed ten people. Sima comments: "*Gu* means winnowing. A small winnowing basket is called *ce*. *Bo jing* means sifting rice." Cheng explains: "*Bo* means winnowing dust." When the authorities conscripted soldiers, Zhili rolled up his sleeves and wandered among them; Guo observes: "Relying on his uselessness, he did not hide himself." When the state undertook great labor projects, Zhili, citing his chronic illness, was exempt from service; Xuan notes: "He could not perform labor." When the authorities distributed grain to the sick, he received three *zhong* and ten bundles of firewood. Sima explains: "Six *hu* and four *dou* make one *zhong*." Thus, one whose form was deformed could still nourish his body and live out his natural years—how much more so one whose virtue is deformed!

Confucius traveled to Chu, where the madman Jieyu wandered near his gate, singing: "O phoenix! O phoenix! How your virtue has declined! The future cannot be awaited, the past cannot be retrieved. Guo explains: "One must act according to the present moment." When the world possesses the Dao, the sage accomplishes his work; Xuan comments: "He fulfills his purpose." Su Yu notes: "Zhuangzi alters the phrasing to show that the times are not favorable. If one lives in an age with the Dao, one would gladly serve the world, not merely preserve one’s life." chunks.translated_text:
Within, virtue is fully replete, and of itself bears outward signs of verification. In Lu there was a foot-amputee named Wang Tai—Li [Yi] notes: "Amputated feet are called *wu*." Those who followed him in study were as numerous as those who followed Confucius. Guo [Xiang] comments: "His disciples rivaled Confucius in number." Chang Ji asked Confucius, saying: "Wang Tai is a foot-amputee, yet those who follow him in study divide Lu equally with you." *Shiwen* notes: "Chang Ji—some say a disciple of Confucius; others, a worthy of Lu." "He stands without teaching, sits without discourse; yet those who go to him empty return full. His disciples all gain something. Is there truly a teaching without words, a shaping of the heart without form?" Xuan [Ying] comments: "Silent transformation." "What manner of man is he?"

Confucius said: "This Master is a sage. I, Qiu, have merely lagged behind and not yet gone to him. I intend to take him as my teacher—how much more those who are not my equal! Why only Lu! I would lead all under Heaven to follow him."

Chang Ji said: "He is a foot-amputee, yet he surpasses you, Master—his distinction from the common is indeed great. If this is so, how does he employ his mind?" Confucius said: "Life and death are great indeed, yet he does not change with them. His person moves with change, yet life and death do not alter him. Though heaven and earth collapse, he will not lose himself with them." Cheng [Xuanying] comments: "Lose: to be lost." "He does not follow them into ruin. He examines the flawless and does not shift with things." Guo Qingfan notes: "*Jia* is a scribal error for *xia*. The *Huainanzi*’s *Jingshen Xun* reads *shen hu wu xia*—'he examines his own flawlessness.' Thus he lets things shift of themselves without being enslaved by them. In the *Zuozhuan*, 'Fu Xia' appears in the *Zheng Shijia* as 'Fu Jia'; in the *Liji*’s *Tan Gong*, 'Gongjian Jia' appears in the *Hanshu*’s *Renbiao* as 'Gongjian Xia.' *Xia* and *jia* are graphically similar and easily confused." "He commands the transformations of things while guarding their root."

Xuan [Ying] comments: "He governs the transformations of things, holding fast to their pivot."

Chang Ji said: "What does this mean?" Confucius said: "Viewed from what makes them different, the liver and gallbladder are as distant as Chu and Yue—though part of one body, the world sees them as distinct. Viewed from what makes them the same, the myriad things are all one—all are a single thing between heaven and earth. If this is so, then he does not know what suits the ears and eyes—what the ears and eyes deem fitting for sound and form—yet his mind roams in the harmony of virtue." Guo [Xiang] comments: "He releases his mind amid the Dao and virtue, and all is vast and without obstruction." "He sees things in their unity and does not perceive their loss." Xuan [Ying] comments: "He sees the myriad things as one, without gain or loss." "He regards the loss of his foot as the shedding of dust."

Chang Ji said: "He cultivates himself—this is all Wang Tai can do. With his knowledge, he attains his heart; with his true knowing, he recovers the principle of his mind. With his heart, he attains the constant heart—again, with the principle of his mind, he awakens to the heart-principle constant through past and present. Why then do people flock to him?" *Zui*: to gather.

Confucius said: "People do not mirror themselves in flowing water but in still water—only stillness can still the many who seek stillness." Cheng [Xuanying] comments: "Mirror: to reflect." Xuan [Ying] comments: "Water does not seek to mirror, yet people come to mirror themselves in it. Only by being still can it still those who seek stillness." "Receiving its mandate from earth, only the pine and cypress remain—standing alone, green in winter and summer. Receiving its mandate from heaven, only Shun stands upright." Guo [Xiang] comments: "Below, only the pine and cypress stand alone; above, only the sage stands alone. Thus all who are not upright come seeking uprightness. If all things were evergreen, the pine and cypress would not be prized; if all people were self-upright, none would admire the great sage and flock to him." Cheng [Xuanying] comments: "The human head is above; remove it, and one dies. The tree’s root is below; remove it, and it dies. Thus we call humans 'upper heads' and trees 'lower heads.' The upper head eats the side heads, the side heads eat the lower heads. The lower heads are grasses and trees; the side heads, insects and beasts." "Fortunate is he who can upright his life, thereby uprighting the lives of others." Xuan [Ying] comments: "Shun could upright his own nature, and the natures of things all received uprightness of themselves."

As for the proof of preserving one’s original state—what is its evidence? The reality of fearlessness. A single brave warrior, boldly entering the nine armies—Cui [Zhuan] comments: "The Son of Heaven has six armies; the feudal lords, three—together, nine armies." He seeks fame and can compel himself—yet even he is like this. How much more one who governs heaven and earth, treasuries the myriad things—Cheng [Xuanying] comments: "He holds the warp of the two powers and embraces the cosmos"—who regards the six limbs as mere lodging—Xuan [Ying] comments: "*Zhi*: merely. He treats the six limbs as his temporary abode." Cheng [Xuanying] comments: "The six limbs: head, torso, and four limbs." "Takes the ears and eyes as mere semblances, and knows with the knowing of unity—*zhi* above refers to wisdom; *zhi* below, to its object. Pure and without duality. Has his heart never died?" Xuan [Ying] comments: "He attains the constant heart, unchanged by life and death." "He will choose a day to ascend in transcendence." *Jia*: Xu [Shen] reads as *xia*. Xuan [Ying] comments: "The *Liji* says: 'The Son of Heaven ascends in transcendence.' Here, it signifies departing the world and standing alone."

chunks.translated_text:
"Choosing a day" means selecting a specific day. *Note*: This refers to the Yellow Emperor’s journey to the Great Purity. Yet men cannot but follow such a path. Xuan [Ying] comments: "Men cannot abandon it of their own accord." How then would he deign to make worldly affairs his concern?

This answers Chang Ji’s suspicion that Dai might harbor ambitions to sway the masses.

Shentu Jia, an amputee, studied under Bohun Wuren alongside Zichan of Zheng. (In the "Miscellaneous Chapters," it is written as "Maoren.") Zichan said to Shentu Jia: "If I leave first, you stay behind; if you leave first, I will stay behind." Guo [Xiang] comments: "He was ashamed to walk alongside an amputee." The next day, they again sat together in the same hall. Zichan said to Shentu Jia: "If I leave first, you stay behind; if you leave first, I will stay behind. Now that I am about to leave, can you not stay behind? Or is it that you cannot?" Guo [Xiang] comments: "He asked bluntly, hoping Shentu Jia would not walk alongside him." "Moreover, when you see the one in power, you do not yield—do you consider yourself equal to the one in power?" *Zhizheng*: Zichan refers to himself. *Wei*: to avoid. *Ye qi*: to be equal. He rebuked Shentu Jia for his lack of deference.

Shentu Jia replied: "In the Master’s gate, are there truly those who take pride in their power as you do? The gate of Master Bohun values virtue and power—how could it harbor those who boast of their authority as you do? You delight in your own power and thus place yourself above others! I have heard it said: ‘When a mirror is bright, dust does not settle; if dust settles, the mirror is no longer bright.’ To dwell long with the worthy is to be without fault." *Zhi*: to settle. A clear mirror gathers no dust; to be near the virtuous is to be without fault. "Now, the greater one you seek is the Master, yet you still speak in this way—is this not a fault?" Xuan [Ying] comments: "*Qu da*: to seek broad understanding." *Note*: *Qu da* means to hold in high regard.

Zichan said: "Since you are as you are—already maimed in form—do you still vie with Yao in goodness?" Xuan [Ying] comments: "Yao represents the pinnacle of goodness, hence the comparison." "Do you not reflect that your virtue is insufficient?" Xuan [Ying] comments: "Considering your past conduct, you must have committed faults that led to your amputation—do you not reflect on this?"

Shentu Jia said: "Those who openly acknowledge their faults yet do not deserve to lose their limbs are many; those who do not acknowledge their faults yet do not deserve to keep their limbs are few. *Zhuang*: to make manifest. Many openly declare their transgressions yet do not deserve to lose their feet; few do not declare their transgressions yet still lose their feet. To know there is nothing to be done and accept it as fate—only those of virtue can do this." Xuan [Ying] comments: "To regard amputation as the natural course of fate and not be troubled by it—only those of virtue can do this." "Wandering within Yi’s drawn bow, the center is the mark, yet whether one hits it or not is a matter of fate. The first two *zhong* are read as written; the latter two are pronounced *zhòng*. The drawn bow of Yi is a metaphor for the net of punishment. To dwell within the net of punishment, who can be certain they are without fault? That one is not struck by punishment is merely a matter of chance. Many with whole limbs mock me for my incomplete limbs. I was enraged, but when I came to the Master’s place, my anger dissipated and I returned to myself." Guo [Xiang] comments: "He abandoned his former anger and returned to his usual state." "Was it not the Master who cleansed me with goodness? He purified my heart’s burdens with the Way of virtue. I have accompanied you, Master, for nineteen years, yet you have never once regarded me as an amputee. I have never heard the Master reject me for my maimed form. Now you and I wander within the realm of form and bone, befriending one another through virtue and power. Yet you seek me out beyond the realm of form and bone, measuring me by outward traces. Is this not a fault?"

Zichan, startled, changed his expression and said: "Do not speak thus!" He rose in apology. *Nai zhe*: meaning "like this." *Zi wu nai cheng*: "Do not speak in this way." In the "Great Master" chapter, "not knowing why it is thus" also means "not knowing why it is like this."

In Lu, there was an amputee named Shushan Wuzhi. Li [Yi] comments: "Shushan is his clan name." Xuan [Ying] comments: "Without toes, he took it as his name." He came to see Confucius on his heels. Cui [Wei] comments: "Without toes, he walked on his heels." Confucius said: "You were not careful, and already you have suffered such misfortune. Though you come now, what can be done?" Wuzhi said: "I was ignorant of my duties and recklessly used my body, which is why I lost my feet. Now that I have come, what remains is something more honorable than feet." Xuan [Ying] comments: "What is more honorable than feet does not reside in the body." "I strive to preserve it whole. Heaven covers all without exception; Earth bears all without exception. I took you, Master, to be like Heaven and Earth—how could I have known you would be like this?"

Confucius said: "I am indeed narrow-minded. Why do you not come in? Please share what you have heard!" Wuzhi departed. Xuan [Ying] comments: "He left directly." Confucius said: "Disciples, take heed! Women who saw him would beg their parents, saying, "I would rather be this man’s concubine than another’s wife," and this happened more than ten times without cease. He never initiated speech, only responding in harmony. He never took the lead—only after sensing another’s intent did he reply. Without the rank of a ruler, he saved others from mortal peril. Without amassing wealth, he filled others’ bellies. Though his ugliness startled the world, he did not move people with beauty. Harmonious yet never leading, he never drew others to himself. His knowledge did not extend beyond his immediate domain, nor did his fame reach far beyond his borders. Yet men and women alike gathered before him. This must be because he possessed something beyond ordinary men.

I summoned him to observe him, and indeed, his ugliness startled the world. After less than a month in my company, I began to sense the depth of his character. Before a year had passed, I trusted him completely. When the state had no minister, I offered him the governance of the realm. He responded only after long hesitation, as if reluctant, and his words seemed to drift away, untethered to any intent. I felt ashamed, yet in the end, I entrusted him with the state. Soon after, he left me and departed. I grieved as if I had lost something, as if no one remained to share the joy of ruling this land. What manner of man is he?"

Confucius said: "I once traveled to Chu and saw young pigs nursing from their dead mother. After a moment, they glanced around in alarm and all abandoned her to flee. They were startled because she no longer saw them, no longer bore the likeness of the living. What they loved in their mother was not her form, but what animated her form. When warriors die in battle, their burials do not include the ceremonial *sha* ornaments, for these are the trappings of martial prowess, and the dead possess no such prowess. When a man’s feet are severed, his shoes are not cherished, for they are made for feet, and he has none. In neither case does the root remain.

The palace women who serve the Son of Heaven do not cut their nails or pierce their ears; those who take wives remain outside the household, not subject to further service. Preserving the body’s wholeness is sufficient to inspire such care—how much more so for one whose virtue is complete! Now, Aitai Tuo gains trust without speaking, draws affection without merit, and is offered a kingdom with such urgency that one fears he might refuse. This must be because his talents are whole and his virtue unmanifest."

Duke Ai said: "What do you mean by *talents being whole*?"

Confucius said: "Life and death, survival and ruin, poverty and wealth, worthiness and unworthiness, slander and praise, hunger and thirst, cold and heat—these are the changes of affairs, the movements of fate. They alternate before us day and night, yet knowledge cannot trace their beginnings. Thus, they are not enough to disturb one’s harmony or enter the mind’s sanctuary. One should allow them to flow smoothly without losing joy, ensuring that day and night, without interruption, one’s presence brings the vitality of spring to all things."

One who fails to forget what ought to be forgotten, yet forgets what ought not to be forgotten—this is called true forgetting. Form should be forgotten, virtue should not be forgotten; to do the opposite is genuine oblivion. Thus the sage wanders where he will, letting his mind roam in emptiness. Yet knowledge becomes a snare: the movement of wisdom and cunning spawns offshoots and entanglements. Constraint becomes glue: rites and trust bind and fasten. Virtue becomes a bond: the broad cultivation of virtuous intent creates mutual attachment. Craft becomes commerce: skillful transformation and accumulation facilitate trade.

The sage does not scheme—what use is knowledge? With no plans in mind, why employ wit? He does not carve—what use is glue? Unhewn substance needs no constraint. He suffers no loss—what use is virtue? Virtue means attainment; with nothing lost, why summon others through virtue? He does not traffic—what use is commerce? Valuing no goods, he has no need for trade. These four are the Heavenly Provisions. The Heavenly Provisions are Heaven’s sustenance. *Shiwen* notes: “Provisions means nourishment.” Knowledge, constraint, virtue, and craft—these are how Heaven nourishes man. Heaven’s nourishment is how Heaven feeds him. Having received sustenance from Heaven, why employ man? Having received Heaven’s sustenance, one should preserve one’s natural state, not adulterate it with human artifice.

He has the form of a man, but not the passions of a man—banishing all emotion. Having the form of a man, he mingles with men; *Cheng* comments: “Blending light and merging traces.” Lacking the passions of a man, right and wrong find no hold in him—cutting off the roots of right and wrong. How tiny and slight! This is how he belongs to man. How towering and vast! This is how he completes his Heaven. *Cui* comments: “Resembling men makes him small; aligning with Heaven makes him great.” *Cheng* comments: “Towering, a description of great height.”

Huizi said to Zhuangzi: “Do men truly have no passions?”
Zhuangzi said: “Yes.”
Huizi said: “If a man has no passions, how can he be called a man?”
Zhuangzi said: “The Dao gives him his appearance, Heaven gives him his form. *Cheng* comments: ‘The Dao of emptiness and penetration shapes his countenance; the principle of spontaneity endows his form.’ How can he not be called a man?”
Huizi said: “If he is called a man, how can he have no passions?”
Zhuangzi said: “This is not what I mean by passions. *Xuan* comments: ‘Huizi first misconstrues the word *passions*.’ *Case*: Guo takes *this* to refer to right and wrong, which is incorrect. What I mean by having no passions is that a man does not allow likes and dislikes to inwardly harm his person, but constantly follows nature without embellishing life.” *Xuan* comments: “He adheres to the principle of life without adding human artifice.”
Huizi said: “If one does not embellish life, how can one have a body?” *Cheng* comments: “If one does not rely on the way of embellishing life, how can one have a body?”
Zhuangzi said: “The Dao gives him his appearance, Heaven gives him his form—he does not allow likes and dislikes to inwardly harm his person. This is how he has a body. Now you estrange your spirit, exhaust your essence, lean against a tree to chant, and rest on a withered catalpa to doze. *Cheng* comments: ‘Withered catalpa’ refers to a knee-high desk. Huizi estranges his spirit and wearies his essence, so when he walks he leans against a tree to chant, and when he sits he rests on a desk to discourse, his body weary and his mind spent, fatigued and dozing.” Heaven chose your form—*chose* is to be understood as in Mencius’ “Heaven chose and sent you.” Yet you clamor about “hard and white”! How is this different from Gongsun Long’s “hard and white” argument? chunks.original_text: 本篇云：「人犹效之。 」效之言师也。 又云：「吾师乎！ 吾师乎！ 」以道为师也。 宗者，主也。 知天之所为，知人之所为者，至矣。 知天之所为者，天而生也； 凡物皆自然而生，则当顺其自然。 知人之所为者，以其知之所知，以养其知之所不知，终其天年而不中道夭者，是知之盛也。 两其知，音智。 不强知，则智得所养。 郭云：「知人之所为者有分，故任而不强也； 知人之所知者有极，故用而不荡也。 故所知不以无涯自困。 」虽然，有患。 成云：「知虽盛美，犹有患累，不若忘知而任独也。 」夫知有所待而后当，其所待者特未定也。 成云：「知必对境，非境不当。 境既生灭不定，知亦待夺无常。 唯当境、知两忘，然后无患。 」庸讵知吾所谓天之非人乎？ 所谓人之非天乎？ 成云：「知能运用，无非自然。 是知天之与人，理归无二，故谓天即人，谓人即天。 所谓吾者，庄生自称。 此则泯合天人，混同物我也。 」且有真人，而后有真知。 郭云：「有真人，而后天下之知皆得其真而不可乱。 」何谓真人？ 古之真人，不逆寡，虚怀任物，虽寡少，不逆忤。 不雄成，不以成功自雄。 不谟士。 成云：「虚夷而士众自归，非谋谟招致。 」若然者，过而弗悔，当而不自得也。 成云：「天时已过，曾无悔吝之心； 分命偶当，不以自得为美。 」若然者，登高不栗，入水不濡，入火不热。 是知之能登假于道也若此。 危难生死，不以介怀。 其能登至于道，非世之所为知也。 古之真人，其寝不梦，成云：「绝思想，故寝寐寂泊。 」其觉无忧，郭云：「随所寓而安。 」其食不甘，成云：「不耽滋味。 」其息深深。 李云：「内息之貌。 」真人之息以踵，成云：「踵，足根。 」宣云：「呼吸通于涌泉。 」众人之息以喉。 宣云：「止于厌会之际。 」屈服者，其嗌言若哇。 屈服，谓议论为人所屈。 嗌，喉咽也。 嗌，声之未出； 言，声之已出。 吞吐之际，如欲哇然，以状无养之人。 其耆欲深者，其天机浅。 情欲深重，机神浅钝。 古之真人，不知说生，不知恶死； 郭云：「与化为体。 」其出不欣，其入不距； 释文：「距，本又作拒。 李云：『欣出则营生，拒入则恶死。 』」翛然而往，翛然而来而已矣。 成云：「翛然，无系貌。 」不忘其所始，不求其所终； 宣云：「知生之源，任死之归。 」受而喜之，宣云：「 受生之后，常自得。 」忘而复之。 宣云：「忘其死，而复归于天。 」是之谓不以心捐道，不以人助天。 是之谓真人。 郭云：「物之感人无穷，人之逐欲无节，则天理灭矣。 真人知用心则背道，助天则伤生，故不为也。 」俞云：「据郭注，捐疑偝之误。 」若然者，其心志，宣云：「志当作忘。 无思。 」其容寂，宣云：「无为。 」其颡頯，宣云：「颡，额也。 」頯，大朴貌，宣云：「恢，上声。 」凄然似秋，暖然似春，郭云：「杀物非为威，生物非为仁。 」喜怒通四时，宣云：「喜怒皆无心，如四时之运。 」与物有宜，而莫知其极。 随事合宜，而莫窥其际。
chunks.translated_text: The present passage states: “People still imitate him.” *Imitate* means to take as teacher. It also says: “My teacher! My teacher!”—taking the Dao as teacher. *Zong* means “master.” To know what Heaven does and to know what man does is to reach the ultimate. To know what Heaven does is to know that it gives life: all things arise spontaneously, so one should accord with their spontaneity. To know what man does is to use what his knowledge knows to nourish what his knowledge does not know, so that he completes his Heaven-appointed years without dying prematurely—this is the fullness of knowledge. *Liang qi zhi* is read as *zhi* (knowledge). If one does not force knowledge, then knowledge is properly nourished. Guo comments: “What man does has its limits, so one should follow without forcing; what man knows has its bounds, so one should use without excess. Thus, what one knows does not become self-entangling through boundlessness.” Even so, there is trouble. Cheng comments: “Though knowledge is full and fine, it still brings trouble and encumbrance—it is not as good as forgetting knowledge and following the solitary.” For knowledge must await something before it is fitting, and what it awaits is especially uncertain. Cheng comments: “Knowledge must face an object; without an object, it is not fitting. Since objects arise and vanish unpredictably, knowledge too is contingent and inconstant. Only when both object and knowledge are forgotten can trouble be avoided.” How do we know that what I call Heaven is not man? That what I call man is not Heaven? Cheng comments: “Knowledge can be applied, but all is natural. Thus, Heaven and man are one in principle, so that to call Heaven is to call man, and to call man is to call Heaven. *What I call* refers to Zhuangzi’s self-reference. Here, Heaven and man are merged, self and things made one.” Only when there is a true person is there true knowledge. Guo comments: “Only when there is a true person do all the knowledges under Heaven attain their truth and cannot be confounded.” What is a true person? The true persons of old did not oppose the few—with empty mind, they accepted things, and though few, they did not resist. They did not boast of success, did not take achievement as a cause for pride. They did not scheme for scholars. Cheng comments: “With emptiness and equanimity, scholars naturally gather—no scheming is needed to attract them.” Such persons, when they err, do not regret; when they are right, do not feel self-satisfied. Cheng comments: “When the time has passed, they have no regret or remorse; when their allotted fate happens to be fitting, they do not take it as a personal virtue.” Such persons ascend heights without trembling, enter water without getting wet, enter fire without feeling heat. Their knowledge’s ability to ascend and lodge in the Dao is like this. They do not take peril, difficulty, life, or death to heart. Their ability to ascend to the Dao is not what the world’s knowledge can comprehend. The true persons of old slept without dreaming. Cheng comments: “They cut off thought, so their sleep was still and empty.” When awake, they had no cares. Guo comments: “They were at ease wherever they dwelled.” They did not relish their food. Cheng comments: “They did not indulge in flavors.” Their breathing was deep. Li comments: “The appearance of inner breathing.” The true person’s breathing reaches the heels. Cheng comments: “*Heels* means the soles of the feet.” Xuan comments: “Breath circulates to the *yongquan* point.” The breathing of ordinary people reaches only the throat. Xuan comments: “It stops at the juncture of the epiglottis.” Those who are overborne in debate have their throats choked as if retching. *Overborne* means being bested in argument. *Throat* refers to the larynx. *Choked* is before the voice comes out; *words* are after the voice comes out. In the moment of swallowing and emitting, it is as if retching—this describes those without cultivation. The deeper their desires, the shallower their Heavenly mechanism. With deep passions and desires, their spirit-mechanism is dull and sluggish. The true persons of old did not delight in life, did not hate death. Guo comments: “They took transformation as their body.” They did not rejoice at going out, did not resist coming in. *Shiwen* notes: “*Resist* is also written as *reject*. Li comments: ‘Rejoicing at going out means scheming for life; resisting coming in means hating death.’” They went *xiaoran*, they came *xiaoran*—that is all. Cheng comments: “*Xiaoran* means unentangled.” They did not forget their beginning, did not seek their end. Xuan comments: “They knew the source of life and entrusted the return of death.” They received and rejoiced in it. Xuan comments: “After receiving life, they were always content.” They forgot and returned to it. Xuan comments: “They forgot death and returned to Heaven.” This is called not using the mind to cast aside the Dao, not using man to assist Heaven. This is called the true person. Guo comments: “The things that move people are endless; the desires that people pursue are boundless—then the Heavenly principle is extinguished. The true person knows that using the mind goes against the Dao, and assisting Heaven harms life, so he does not do so.” Yu comments: “According to Guo’s commentary, *cast aside* is likely a mistake for *go against*.” Such persons’ minds were forgetful. Xuan comments: “*Minds* should be *forgetfulness*. No thought.” Their countenance was still. Xuan comments: “No action.” Their foreheads were broad. Xuan comments: “*Foreheads* means the brow.” *Broad* describes great simplicity. Xuan comments: “Read *hui* with the rising tone.” They were bleak like autumn, warm like spring. Guo comments: “Killing things is not for might; giving life is not for benevolence.” Their joy and anger corresponded to the four seasons. Xuan comments: “Joy and anger were without intention, like the movements of the four seasons.” They were fitting with things, yet none knew their limit. They were fitting with circumstances, yet none could fathom their bounds.

chunks.original_text: 故圣人之用兵也，亡国而不失人心； 崔云：「亡敌国而得其人心。 」利泽施于万物，不为爱人。 由仁义行，非行仁义。 故乐通物，非圣人也； 不求通物，而物情自通，为圣人。 有亲，非仁也； 至仁则无私亲。 天时，非贤也； 宣云：「择时而动，有计较成败之心。 」利害不通，非君子也； 利害不观其通，故有趋避。 行名失己，非士也； 成云：「必所行求名而失己性，非有道之士。 」亡身不真，非役人也。 宣云：「徒弃其身，而无当真性，为世所役，非能役人。 」若狐不偕、成云：「姓狐，字不偕，尧时贤人，不受尧让，投河而死。 」务光、成云：「夏时人，饵药养性，好鼓琴，汤让天下，不受，负石自沈于庐水。 」伯夷、叔齐、箕子胥余、司马云：「胥余，箕子名。 尸子曰：『箕子胥余，漆身为厉，被发佯狂。 』」纪他、成云：「汤时逸人，闻汤让务光，恐及乎己，遂将弟子，蹈于窾水而死。 申徒狄闻之，因以踣河。 」申徒狄，释文：「殷时人，负石自沈于河。 」是役人之役，适人之适，而不自适其适者也。 郭云：「斯皆舍己效人，徇彼伤我者。 」宣云：「为人用，快人意，与真性何益！ 」古之真人，其状义而不朋，郭云：「与物同宜，而非朋党。 」俞云：「郭注非也。 此言其状，非言其德。 义读为峨。 天道篇『而状义然』，即峨然也。 朋读为崩。 易『朋来无咎』，汉书五行志引作『崩来无咎』，是也。 义而不朋，言其状峨然高大而不崩坏也。 」若不足而不承，宣云：「卑以自牧，而非居人下。 」与乎其觚而不坚也，王云：「觚，特立不群也。 」崔云：「觚，棱也。 」李桢云：「觚是孤借字。 释地『觚竹』，释文：『本又作孤。 』此孤、觚通作之证。 孤特者，方而有棱，故字亦借觚为之。 『与乎其觚』，与『张乎其虚』对文，与当是●之借字。 说文：『●，安行也。 』」案：不坚，谓不固执。 张乎其虚而不华也，成云：「张，广大貌。 」案：廓然清虚，而不浮华。 邴邴乎其似喜乎！ 向云：「邴邴，喜貌。 」郭云：「至人无喜，畅然和适，故似喜也。 」崔乎其不得已乎！ 向云：「崔，动貌。 」成云：「迫而后动，非关先唱，故不得已而应之也。 」滀乎进我色也，简文云：「滀，聚也。 」宣云：「水聚则有光泽。 言和泽之色，令人可亲。 」与乎止我德也，与，相接意。 宣云：「宽闲之德，使我归止。 」厉乎其似世乎！ 崔本「厉」作「广」，当从之。 俞云：「世乃泰之借字。 广与泰义相应。 」郭庆藩云：「厉、广古通借。 泰字作大。 世、大古亦通借。 」謷乎其未可制也，成云：「謷然高远，超于世表，不可禁制。 」连乎其似好闭也，李云：「连，绵长貌。 」郭云：「绵邈深远，莫见其门。 」成云：「默如关闭，不闻见也。 」释文：「好，呼报反。 」悗乎忘其言也。 释文：「悗，忘本反。 」成云：「悗，无心貌。 以上言真人德行，下明其利物为政之方。 」以刑为体，郭云：「刑者治之体，非我为。 」以礼为翼，郭云：「礼者，世所以自行，非我制。 」以知为时，郭云：「知者时之动，非我唱。 」以德为循。 郭云：「德者自彼所循，非我作。 」以刑为体者，绰乎其杀也； 郭云：「任治之自杀，故虽杀而宽。
chunks.translated_text:
Thus, when the sage employs military force, he overthrows states yet does not lose the people’s hearts. Cui comments: “Overthrowing enemy states while winning their people’s hearts.” His beneficence and favor extend to the myriad things, yet not out of love for others. He acts through benevolence and righteousness, yet does not practice benevolence and righteousness. Therefore, one who delights in connecting with things is no sage; one who does not seek to connect with things, yet finds the nature of things naturally aligned, is a sage. Having partiality is not benevolence; perfect benevolence has no private attachments. Following the seasons is not wisdom; Xuan comments: “Choosing the time to act reveals a mind calculating success and failure.” One who does not comprehend the interconnection of benefit and harm is no gentleman; failing to observe their interconnection leads to pursuit and avoidance. Acting for fame at the cost of oneself is no scholar; Cheng comments: “One who seeks fame through action yet loses their true nature is no man of the Dao.” Sacrificing oneself without authenticity is not mastery over others; Xuan comments: “Merely casting aside one’s life without aligning with true nature is to be used by the world, not to use others.” Such were Hu Bujie—Cheng comments: “Surnamed Hu, styled Bujie, a worthy of Yao’s time who refused Yao’s abdication and drowned himself in the river”—Wu Guang—Cheng comments: “A man of the Xia era who cultivated life through herbs, loved playing the zither, and when Tang offered him the throne, refused and drowned himself with a stone in the Lu River”—Boyi and Shuqi, Jizi Xuyu—Sima comments: “Xuyu was Jizi’s name. The *Shizi* states: ‘Jizi Xuyu painted his body to feign leprosy and let his hair loose to feign madness’”—Ji Ta—Cheng comments: “A recluse of Tang’s time who, hearing Tang’s offer to Wu Guang, feared it might extend to himself, led his disciples into the Kuǎn River and drowned”—and Shentu Di—*Shiwen* notes: “A man of the Yin era who drowned himself in the river with a stone.” These were men used by others, following others’ paths, yet never attaining their own true way. Guo comments: “All abandoned themselves to imitate others, harming themselves for others’ sake.” Xuan comments: “Being used by others, pleasing others—what benefit is there to one’s true nature?”

The true person of old had an appearance lofty yet not crumbling. Guo comments: “Accordant with things yet not forming cliques.” Yu comments: “Guo’s note is incorrect. This describes their appearance, not their virtue. *Yi* should be read as *e* (峨). In the *Dao of Heaven* chapter, ‘their appearance *yiran* (义然)’ means *eran* (峨然, towering). *Peng* should be read as *beng* (崩). The *Yijing* says ‘*peng* comes without blame,’ and the *Han Shu Wuxing Zhi* quotes it as ‘*beng* comes without blame.’ *Yi er bu peng* means their appearance was towering and grand yet not crumbling.” They seemed insufficient yet did not submit. Xuan comments: “Humble in self-cultivation yet not subservient to others.” They were solitary yet not rigid. Wang comments: “*Gu* means standing alone, unaligned with the crowd.” Cui comments: “*Gu* means angular.” Li Zhen comments: “*Gu* is a loan for *gu* (孤). The *Er Ya*’s ‘*gu* bamboo’ has a *Shiwen* note: ‘Originally written as *gu* (孤).’ This confirms the interchangeability of *gu* and *gu*. The solitary and independent have edges and corners, hence the character is also borrowed as *gu*. ‘*Yu hu qi gu*’ parallels ‘*zhang hu qi xu*,’ where *yu* should be a loan for *●*. The *Shuowen* states: ‘*●* means walking calmly.’” Note: *Bu jian* means not obstinate. They were expansive in their emptiness yet not ostentatious. Cheng comments: “*Zhang* means vast.” Note: Vast and clear in their emptiness, yet not superficial. They were radiant as if joyful! Xiang comments: “*Bingbing* is the appearance of joy.” Guo comments: “The perfected person has no joy, yet is harmoniously at ease, thus seeming joyful.” They moved as if compelled! Xiang comments: “*Cui* is the appearance of motion.” Cheng comments: “Moved only by necessity, never initiating, thus acting only when unavoidable.” They gathered and enhanced my countenance. Jianwen comments: “*Chu* means to gather.” Xuan comments: “Like water gathering to form a lustrous sheen, their harmonious and gracious demeanor made them approachable.” They drew me in with their virtue. *Yu* conveys the sense of connection. Xuan comments: “Their tranquil and magnanimous virtue made me wish to dwell with them.” They were vast as if embracing the world! Cui’s edition has *guang* (广) for *li* (厉), which should be followed. Yu comments: “*Shi* is a loan for *tai* (泰). *Guang* and *tai* correspond in meaning.” Guo Qingfan comments: “*Li* and *guang* were anciently interchangeable. *Tai* was written as *da* (大). *Shi* and *da* were also interchangeable.” They were towering and beyond control. Cheng comments: “Lofty and distant, transcending the world, they could not be restrained.” They were continuous as if fond of seclusion. Li comments: “*Lian* means the appearance of continuity.” Guo comments: “Vast and remote, their gate unseen.” Cheng comments: “Silent as if sealed, their presence unheard.” *Shiwen* notes: “*Hao* is read as *hu bao* (呼报).” They were absent-minded, forgetting their words. *Shiwen* notes: “*Men* is read as *wang ben* (忘本).” Cheng comments: “*Men* is the appearance of absent-mindedness. The above describes the true person’s virtue; below clarifies their way of governing and benefiting things.”

They took punishment as their foundation. Guo comments: “Punishment is the foundation of governance, not of their own making.” They took ritual as their wings. Guo comments: “Ritual is how the world conducts itself, not of their own creation.” They took knowledge as their timing. Guo comments: “Knowledge moves with the times, not of their own initiation.” They took virtue as their guide. Guo comments: “Virtue is what others follow, not of their own design.” Taking punishment as their foundation, they were lenient in execution. Guo comments: “Entrusting governance to the natural course of execution, thus even in killing, they were magnanimous.”

chunks.original_text: 」以礼为翼者，所以行于世也； 郭云：「顺世所行，故无不行。 」以知为时者，不得已于事也； 知以应时，不得已于世事，随宜付之。 以德为循者，言其与有足者至于丘也，宣云：「德之所在，人人可至，我特循之耳。 如丘之所在，有足者皆可至，我特与同登耳，非自立异。 」案：无意于行，自然而至，故曰「与有足者至」也。 而人真以为勤行者也。 宣云：「人视真人为勤行不怠，岂知其毫末以我与乎！ 」故其好之也一，其弗好之也一。 成云：「既忘怀于美恶，亦遗荡于爱憎。 故好与弗好，出自凡情，而圣智虚融，未尝不一。 」其一也一，其不一也一。 成云：「其一，圣智也； 其不一，凡情也。 凡、圣不二，故不一皆一之。 」其一，与天为徒； 其不一，与人为徒。 成云：「同天人，齐万致，与天而为类也。 彼彼而我我，与人而为徒也。 」天与人不相胜也，是之谓真人。 成云：「虽天无彼我，人有是非，确然谕之，咸归空寂。 若使天胜人劣，岂谓齐乎！ 此又混一天人，冥同胜负，体此趣者，可谓真人。 」死生，命也，其有夜旦之常，天也。 人之有所不得与，皆物之情也。 死生与夜旦等，皆由天命，不可更以人与。 此物之情，实无足系恋也。 彼特以天为父，而身犹爱之，而况其卓乎！ 身知爱天，而况卓然出于天者乎！ 人特以有君为愈乎己，宣云：「势分胜乎己。 」而身犹死之，宣云：「效忠。 」而况其真乎！ 身知爱君，而况确然切于君者乎！
chunks.translated_text:
Taking ritual as their wings, they thereby moved through the world.
Guo comments: “Following what the world already practices, thus nothing was unachievable.”

Taking knowledge as their timing, they acted only when compelled by affairs.
Knowledge responded to the moment, compelled by worldly matters, adapting as circumstances required.

Taking virtue as their guide, it was said that they walked with those who had feet to the hill.
Xuan comments: “Where virtue resides, all may reach it; I merely followed. Like a hill that all with feet may climb, I simply ascended with them—no distinction was made.”
Note: Acting without intent to act, they arrived naturally, thus “walked with those who had feet.”

Yet people truly believed them to be diligent in conduct.
Xuan comments: “People saw the true person as tirelessly active, unaware that not even the slightest part was of their own doing.”

Thus, whether they were loved or not loved, it was all the same.
Cheng comments: “Having forgotten attachment to beauty or ugliness, they also cast aside preferences of love and hate. Thus, whether loved or not loved, it arose from the sentiments of the common, while the sage’s emptiness remained undivided.”

Whether unified or not unified, it was all the same.
Cheng comments: “The unified belongs to the sage; the not unified, to the common. Yet sage and common are not two, thus the not unified is also unified.”

In their unity, they walked with Heaven.
In their disunity, they walked with humanity.
Cheng comments: “Harmonizing with Heaven, equalizing the myriad things—they were of Heaven’s kind. Distinctions of self and other—they walked with humanity.”

That Heaven and humanity do not overcome one another—this is called the true person.
Cheng comments: “Though Heaven has no self or other, and humanity has right and wrong, when clearly illuminated, all returns to emptiness. If Heaven were to overcome and humanity to be inferior, how could they be equal? This is the merging of Heaven and humanity, the obscuring of victory and defeat. One who embodies this is called the true person.”

Life and death are fate; their constancy is like night and day—this is Heaven.
What humanity cannot partake in belongs to the nature of things.
Life and death are like night and day, all determined by Heavenly fate, beyond human intervention. This is the nature of things, truly nothing to cling to.

They regarded Heaven as their father and cherished it—how much more that which stands transcendent!
If one cherishes Heaven as their body does, how much more that which rises transcendent from Heaven!

People consider having a lord superior to themselves.
Xuan comments: “The lord’s position surpasses their own.”
And yet they would die for him.
Xuan comments: “They offer loyalty.”
How much more that which is true!
If one cherishes their lord as their body does, how much more that which is truly aligned with him!

chunks.original_text: 泉涸，鱼相与处于陆，相呴以湿，相濡以沫，不如相忘于江湖。 喻贪生惧死，不如相忘于自然。 「泉涸」四语，又见天运篇。 与其誉尧而非桀，不如两忘而化其道。 宣云：「此道字轻，谓是非之道。 言誉尧非桀，不如两忘其道； 好生恶死，不如两忘其累。 」案：二语又见外物篇，下三字作「闭其所誉」。 夫大块载我以形，劳我以生，佚我以老，息我以死。 故善吾生者，乃所以善吾死也。 宣云：「纯任自然，所以善吾生也。 如是，则死亦不苦矣。 」案：六语又见后。 列子天瑞篇：「人胥知生之乐，未知生之苦； 知老之惫，未知老之逸； 知死之恶，未知死之息也。 」夫藏舟于壑，藏山于泽，岛也。 谓之固矣。 然而夜半有力者负之而走，昧者不知也。 舟可负，山可移。 宣云：「造化默运，而藏者犹谓在其故处。 」藏大小有宜，犹有所遁。 若夫藏天下于天下，而不得所遁，是恒物之大情也。 藏无大小，各有所宜，然无不变之理。 宣云：「遁生于藏之过，若悟天下之理，非我所得私，而因而付之天下，则此理随在与我共之，又乌所遁哉！ 此物理之实也。 」案：恒物之大情，犹言常物之通理。 特犯人之形而犹喜之，若人之形者，万化而未始有极也，其为乐可胜计邪！ 犯与笵同。 见笵人形犹喜之，若人之生无穷，孰不自喜其身者！ 故圣人将游于物之所不得遁而皆存。 宣云：「圣人全体造化，形有生死，而此理已与天地同流，故曰皆存。 」善妖善老，善始善终，人犹效之，又况万物之所系，而一化之所待乎！ 释文：「妖，本又作夭。 」成云：「寿夭老少，都不介怀。 虽未能忘生死，但复无所嫌恶，犹足为物师傅，人仿效之。 况混同万物，冥一变化，为物宗匠，不亦宜乎！ 」夫道，有情有信，无为无形； 宣云：「情者，静之动也； 信者，动之符也。 」成云：「恬然寂寞，无为也； 视之不见，无形也。 」可传而不可受，郭云：「古今传而宅之，莫能受而有之。 」可得而不可见； 成云：「方寸独悟，可得也。 离于形色，不可见也。 」自本自根，宣云：「道为事物根本，更无有为道之根本者，自本自根耳。 」未有天地，自古以固存； 成云：「老子云：『有物混成，先天地生。 』」神鬼神帝，下文堪坏、冯夷等，鬼也； 豨韦、伏羲等，帝也。 其神，皆道神之。 生天生地； 成云：「老子云：『天得一以清，地得一以宁。 』」在太极之先而不为高，在六极之下而不为深； 阴阳未判，是为太极。 天地四方，谓之六极。 成云：「道在太极之先，不为高远； 在六合之下，不为深邃。 」先天地生而不为久，长于上古而不为老。 释文：「长，丁丈反。 」案：此语又见后。

When springs run dry, fish find themselves stranded on land, moistening one another with breath, bedewing one another with foam—better far to forget each other in rivers and lakes. This illustrates how clinging to life and fearing death is inferior to forgetting both in the natural Way.

Rather than praising Yao and condemning Jie, better to forget both and be transformed by the Dao. Xuan comments: “Here *Dao* is used lightly, referring to the way of right and wrong. To praise Yao and condemn Jie is not as good as forgetting both ways; to love life and hate death is not as good as forgetting both burdens.”

For the great clod bears me with form, wearies me with life, eases me with old age, and rests me with death. Thus, to treat my life well is to treat my death well. Xuan comments: “To follow nature purely is to treat my life well. If so, death will not be bitter.” This passage appears again later. As the *Liezi*’s “Heaven’s Auspices” chapter says: “People all know the joy of life but not its suffering; they know the weariness of old age but not its ease; they know the dread of death but not its rest.”

Hiding a boat in a ravine or a mountain in a marsh seems secure—yet in the dead of night, a strong man may carry them away, and the unaware would not know. A boat can be carried off, a mountain moved. Xuan comments: “Creation works in silence, yet those who hide things still believe they remain in their original place.” Whether hiding something large or small, there is always a way for it to escape. But if one hides the world within the world, there is no escape—this is the great truth of all things. Whether hiding something large or small, each has its proper place, yet there is no principle that does not change. Xuan comments: “Escape arises from excessive attachment to hiding. But if one awakens to the principle that the world cannot be privately possessed and instead entrusts it to the world, then this principle will be everywhere shared with me—how could there be any escape? This is the true nature of things.”

Yet people delight in possessing human form—if those with human form are but one of ten thousand transformations without end, how boundless their joy must be! *Fan* (犯) is interchangeable with *fan* (笵). Seeing the form of humanity, they rejoice—if human life is endless, who would not delight in their own existence?

Thus, the sage wanders where nothing can escape and all things abide. Xuan comments: “The sage embodies creation entirely; though form has life and death, this principle already flows with heaven and earth—thus it is said that all things abide.”

Excelling in youth and age, in beginnings and ends, people still emulate them—how much more that on which the myriad things depend and by which all transformations await! The *Shiwen* notes: “*Yao* (妖) is also written as *yao* (夭).” Cheng comments: “Whether long-lived or short-lived, young or old, they remain unconcerned. Though they may not forget life and death, they harbor no aversion—this alone is enough to serve as a teacher for others. How much more when one merges with the myriad things, darkly uniting with transformation, becoming the master of all things!”

The Dao has essence and trustworthiness, yet it is without action or form. Xuan comments: “Essence is the movement of stillness; trustworthiness is the sign of movement.” Cheng comments: “Serene and silent, it is without action; invisible, it is without form.”

It can be transmitted but not received. Guo comments: “It has been passed down through the ages as a dwelling, yet none can receive and possess it.” It can be attained but not seen. Cheng comments: “Through solitary awakening in the heart, it can be attained—but separated from form and color, it cannot be seen.”

It is self-originating, self-rooted. Xuan comments: “The Dao is the root of all things, and there is nothing that serves as its own root—it is self-originating, self-rooted.” Before heaven and earth existed, it was already eternally present. Cheng comments: “As Laozi says: ‘There is a thing formed in chaos, born before heaven and earth.’”

It spiritually empowers ghosts and gods, emperors and lords. Below, Kanpi and Feng Yi are ghosts; Xiwei and Fuxi are emperors—all are spiritually empowered by the Dao. It gives birth to heaven and earth. Cheng comments: “As Laozi says: ‘Heaven attains the One and becomes clear; earth attains the One and becomes stable.’”

It exists before the Supreme Ultimate yet is not high; it exists below the Six Directions yet is not deep. Before yin and yang divided, this was called the Supreme Ultimate. Heaven, earth, and the four directions are called the Six Directions. Cheng comments: “The Dao exists before the Supreme Ultimate yet is not lofty; it exists below the Six Directions yet is not profound.”

It precedes heaven and earth yet is not ancient; it is older than antiquity yet is not aged. The *Shiwen* notes: “*Zhang* (长) is read as *dingzhang*.” This passage appears again later.

The Weaving Dipper attained it and has endured through all ages without error. Cheng comments: “The Northern Dipper serves as the guiding cord for all stars, hence called the Weaving Dipper. Jianwu attained it and thereby dwelt upon the great mountains. Sima comments: “A mountain spirit, undying, who lived until the time of Confucius.” Cheng comments: “Having attained the Dao, he dwelt on Mount Tai, becoming the spirit of Mount Tai.”

The Yellow Emperor attained it and thereby ascended to the cloudy heavens. Cui comments: “The Yellow Emperor attained the Dao and ascended to heaven.”

Zhuanxu attained it and thereby resided in the Dark Palace. Li comments: “Zhuanxu was Gaoyang. The Dark Palace is the palace of the north. The *Monthly Ordinances* states: ‘Its sovereign is Zhuanxu; its spirit is Xuanming.’” Cheng comments: “Having attained the Dao, he became the emperor of the north. *Xuan* is the color of the north, hence he resided in the Dark Palace.”

Yuqiong attained it and stood at the North Pole. *Shiwen* notes: “The *Classic of Mountains and Seas* states: ‘Yuqiong of the north, black-bodied with human hands and feet, rides two dragons.’ Guo Pu takes him as a water spirit, with a human face and bird’s body. Jianwen comments: ‘The spirit of the Northern Sea, also named Yujing, was the grandson of the Yellow Emperor.’”

The Queen Mother of the West attained it and sat upon Shaoguang. None knew her beginning; none knew her end. *Shiwen* notes: “The *Classic of Mountains and Seas* states: ‘The Queen Mother of the West resembles a human, with a dog’s tail, disheveled hair, and a sheng headdress, skilled in whistling, dwelling at the edge of the sea.’ The *Inner Biography of Emperor Wu of Han* states: ‘The Queen Mother of the West and the Lady of the Upper Prime descended to the emperor, beautiful in countenance, divine immortals.’ Cui comments: ‘Shaoguang is the name of a mountain.’ Another says: It is the name of the empty realm of the west.”

Pengzu attained it, reaching from the time of Youyu down to the Five Hegemons. Cui comments: “Pengzu lived seven hundred years; some consider him an immortal, undying.” Cheng comments: “From the time of Youyu down to Yin and Zhou, he lived eight hundred years in all.”

Fuyue attained it and thereby assisted King Wu Ding, governing the realm. He rode the Eastern Ridge, mounted the Tail of the Winnowing Basket, and ranked among the constellations. Sima comments: “The Eastern Ridge lies between the Winnowing Basket and the Dipper, the eastern ridge of the Celestial Ford. The *Star Canon* states: ‘The star Fuyue lies above the Tail.’” Cui comments: “When Fuyue died, his spirit rode the Eastern Ridge and lodged in the Dragon’s Tail, becoming a constellation.” *Shiwen* notes: “Cui’s edition includes below: ‘Born without parents, at death he ascended in假, and after three years his form vanished—this speaks of the spirit that cannot be named.’” The text below cites seven instances to illustrate this.

The Dao as a thing aids without limit, welcoming endless life and sending off boundless death.” “There is nothing it does not destroy, nothing it does not complete.” Cheng comments: “Without sending, yet sending—nothing is not destroyed; without welcoming, yet welcoming—nothing is not completed.” “Its name is called ‘tranquil amidst entanglement.’” “‘Tranquil amidst entanglement’ means that only after entanglement does one attain completion.” Guo Songtao comments: “Mencius’ Zhao commentary: ‘Entanglement means pressing.’ The perceptions of self and things, life and death press within; the mechanisms of welcoming and sending, completion and destruction press without. The Maker of Things would fashion me into this cramped form!" Cheng comments: "Ziyu laments his own condition." Sima explains: "Cramped—his body is contorted and contracted." His spine was bent, his back hunched, his five vital tubes protruding upward—these were the five visceral conduits turned outward. His chin sank into his navel, his shoulders rose above his crown, and his nape pointed heavenward. Li explains: "His nape, like an excrescence, jutted upward." The qi of yin and yang had fallen into disorder. Yet his heart remained at ease, untroubled. He hobbled swiftly to the well and gazed into it, saying: "Alas! Would the Maker of Things fashion me into this cramped form again!" He sighed once more.

Zisi asked: "Do you resent this?"
Ziyu replied: "No, not at all. Why should I resent it? If gradually my left arm were transformed into a rooster, I would use it to mark the watches of the night. If my right arm were transformed into a crossbow pellet, I would use it to seek roasted owl. If my tailbone were transformed into a wheel and my spirit into a horse, I would ride it—why would I need another steed?" Guo comments: "There is no going forth without cause, and no cause that cannot be followed." Moreover, to gain is to meet one’s time, and to lose is to follow the natural course. Abiding in one’s time and following the natural course, sorrow and joy cannot enter. This is what the ancients called "suspended release." Cheng comments: "To gain is to live; to lose is to die." As in the *Yangsheng zhu* chapter: "To come is to meet one’s time; to depart is to follow the natural course. Abiding in one’s time and following the natural course, sorrow and joy cannot enter. The ancients called this the release of the bound by the Sovereign." This passage confirms it. Yet one who cannot release themselves is bound by things. Guo comments: "If one cannot release themselves, the myriad things will bind them together." Moreover, things have long been unable to overcome Heaven—why should I resent it?"

Soon after, Zilai fell ill, gasping as he neared death. His wife and children gathered around him, weeping. Cheng comments: "Gasping—his breath was labored." Zili went to visit him and shouted: "Begone!"

Leaning against the doorframe, Zili spoke to him: "How wondrous is the Creator! What will it make of you next? What thing will it make you? Where will it send you? Will it make you a rat’s liver? A bug’s arm?" Wang comments: "Taking the most minute and base things."

Zilai said: "To parents, a child must follow their commands, no matter if they send them east, west, south, or north. The yin and yang of the world are no less to a person than their parents. Cheng comments: 'The transformations of yin and yang—how are they any different from one’s two parents?' If they press me toward death and I do not heed them, then I am obstinate. What fault is theirs? They are yin and yang. Obstinate means disobedient. Xuan comments: '近 means to press close.'

"The great clod bears me with form, labors me with life, eases me with old age, and rests me with death. Thus, to treat my life well is to treat my death well." These six phrases also appear in the *Da zongshi* chapter.

"Now, a great smith forging metal—if the metal leaps up and says, 'I must become a *Mo* sword!' the great smith will surely deem it an inauspicious metal. A great smith is a metal-forging artisan. If one, upon assuming human form, says, 'I am human! I am human!' the Creator will surely deem them an inauspicious person. *Fan* is the same as *fan* (mold). To become human by chance, then delight in it and cherish it as something distinct from other things—this is what the Creator will deem inauspicious.

"Now, take heaven and earth as a great furnace and the Creator as a great smith—where could one go and not be acceptable?" Rat’s liver or bug’s arm—what concern are they to one’s thoughts!

Then he fell into a deep sleep and awoke transformed. To become human is to sleep; to depart in length is to awaken.

Zisang Hu, Mengzi Fan, and Ziqin Zhang were three friends who said to one another: "Who can join together in non-joining, act for one another in non-acting?" Cheng comments: "Like the hundred parts of the body, each with its own function, mutually serving one another without intent to join or act—yet the work of mutual aid is accomplished. Thus, to move together in non-joining and befriend in non-acting is the same."

"Who can ascend to heaven and wander in the mists?" Xuan comments: "To rise beyond things." "Who can twist and turn without end?" Li comments: "挠挑 means to meander, to wander in the vast and mysterious." "Who can forget life and have no end or limit?" Xuan comments: "Neither delighting in life nor loathing death."

The three looked at one another and smiled, their hearts in perfect accord, and so they became friends.

Some wove bamboo mats—Li comments: "曲 means silkworm trays"—while others played the zither, harmonizing as they sang: "Alas, Zisang Hu! Alas, Zisang Hu! You have returned to your true nature, while we still remain human, alas!" Cheng comments: "猗 is a harmonizing sound."

Zigong hurried forward and said: "May I ask—is it proper to sing before the corpse?"

The two looked at each other and smiled, saying: "What does he know of the meaning of ritual?" *This* refers to Zigong.

Zigong returned and reported to Confucius: "What sort of men are they? They lack cultivated conduct, disregard their own bodies, sing before the corpse, and show no change in countenance. I have no name for them. What sort of men are they?"

Confucius said: "They wander beyond the bounds, while I wander within them. Cheng comments: '方 means boundary.' Beyond and within do not reach one another, and yet I sent you to offer condolences—how crude of me!

"They are about to become companions to the Creator." Wang Yinzhi comments: "为人 means 'to be a companion.' The *Huainanzi*’s *Yuandao* chapter says, 'To be companions to the Creator,' and the *Qisu* chapter says, 'Above, they befriend the divine and enlightened; below, they become companions to the Creator'—this is the clearest proof."

"Yet they wander in the single qi of heaven and earth. Xuan comments: 'A type of ulcer.' Cheng comments: 'Qi scatters in death, like an abscess bursting—nothing to regret.'

"Those who are like this—how could they know where life and death, before and after, reside?" Xuan comments: "A single qi in circulation."

"Borrowing from different things, entrusting themselves to a shared body—Xuan comments: "As in the *Yuanjue Jing*’s teaching that earth, wind, water, and fire combine to form the body—seeing life as mere chance." Forgetting their liver and gall, disregarding their ears and eyes—Xuan comments: "Disregarding the body, seeing death as mere chance." Reversing and repeating, beginning and ending, not knowing the head or tail, coming and going in life and death, never knowing their limit.

"Vaguely wandering beyond the dust and grime, carefree in the work of non-action." Cheng comments: "芒然 means the appearance of unawareness. To be unrestrained beyond the dust’s burdens, at ease in the realm of clarity and vastness."

Confucius replied: "Qiu is one punished by Heaven."
Cheng comments: "Sacred traces and ritual propriety are but shackles upon form and nature. Since the Master remains within the bounds of the world, he follows the principle of nature—yet is one marked by punishment. Thus, in the 'Virtue Complete' chapter, it is said: *'Punished by Heaven, how could he be freed?*'"
"Nevertheless, I share this with you."
Xuan comments: "He does not wish to conceal what he has attained."

Zigong said: "May I ask about this path?"
Confucius replied: "Fish are made for water, just as humans are made for the Dao. 造 means to reach. Fish that reach water find joy; humans that reach the Dao find joy. Those who are made for water dig ponds to sustain themselves; those made for the Dao find tranquility without effort."
*Shiwen* notes: "池 may also be written as 地." Both versions are valid.
"Fish obtain water and are sustained; humans obtain the Dao and their nature is settled. 生 and 性 are interchangeable. Thus it is said: *Fish forget one another in rivers and lakes; humans forget one another in the arts of the Dao.*"
Xuan comments: "The greater the expanse, the greater the ease—how could it be merely a matter of sustenance and settled nature?"

Zigong said: "May I ask about the *jiren*?"
Sima comments: "畸 means unpaired."
Guo comments: "He asks: Where are those who dwell beyond the bounds of the world and do not pair with convention?"
Confucius replied: "The *jiren* is one unpaired with others yet equal to Heaven."
Sima comments: "侔 means equal."
Cheng comments: "Following their original nature, they align with the principle of nature."
"Thus it is said: *What is a petty person in Heaven is a noble person among humans; what is a noble person among humans is a petty person in Heaven.*"
Xuan comments: "Bound by ritual and propriety, ignorant of the true nature of life and destiny, yet humans call them refined."
*Note: All versions agree on this text. It seems repetitive and without meaning; it should likely read: "What is a noble person in Heaven is a petty person among humans."*
Cheng comments: "Zifan and Qin Zhang, unpaired with convention, are called *jiren*—truly noble persons in Heaven."
*Note: To be unpaired with convention means to reject ritual propriety, so humans all disdain them. Thus it is said: "What is a noble person in Heaven is a petty person among humans." The meaning is clear.*
Su Yu comments: "If we judge the *jiren* by the standards of petty humans, then even Qin Zhang and Mengsun would be deemed unworthy. Could Zhuangzi truly be one who does not understand ritual?"

Yan Hui said: "When his mother died, he wept without tears, his heart felt no grief, and he showed no sorrow in mourning. Lacking these three, he was yet praised throughout Lu for his mastery of mourning rites. Could one truly gain such a reputation without substance? I find this most strange."

*Note: Guo Xiang, Lu Deming, and Cheng Xuanying’s versions end the sentence at "mourning."*
Li Zhen comments: "The meaning remains incomplete. The phrase 'praised throughout Lu' should belong to the preceding clause, akin to the line in 'The Emperor of All Things'—'his merit covered all under Heaven.' The *Shi Yan* states: '弇 means to cover.' The *Shi Ming* says: '盖 means to surpass.' Both imply rising above. Thus, Mengsun Cai’s reputation for mastery of mourning rites surpassed all in Lu."

Confucius said: "Mengsun Cai has exhausted the Way—he has surpassed mere knowledge. As Cheng notes: '进 means to exceed.' Xuan comments: 'He has fully realized the Dao, surpassing those who merely know mourning rites.' He sought simplicity but could not fully attain it. Xuan comments: 'Simplicity means to reduce affairs. Bound by世俗 conventions, he could not entirely dispense with weeping and mourning rites.' Yet he has already simplified much. Xuan comments: 'Still, he wept without tears, felt no grief, and showed no sorrow—this is already a form of simplicity.' Su Yu remarks: 'These two lines are general statements, not specific to Mengsun Cai.' Yao comments: 'Ordinary people are shackled by emotions of life and death, believing sorrow to be natural. Though they cannot fully simplify, they remain unaware that in the truth of nature and destiny, they have already simplified much.' This seems superior to Xuan’s interpretation.*

Mengsun Cai did not know why he lived, nor why he died. Xuan comments: 'He entrusted life and death to nature—this is how he surpassed mere knowledge.' He did not seek what came before, nor what came after. Cheng comments: 'Before refers to life; after, to death. United in life and death, he neither departed nor clung.' Transformed into another thing, he awaited the transformations he could not know! Xuan comments: 'He followed the process of transformation, awaiting whatever unknown changes might come.' Consider: death is transformation into a ghostly thing. But who knows if he might not become a rat’s liver or an insect’s limb—transformations beyond knowing! And if he is about to transform, how could one know he has not already done so? If he is about to remain unchanged, how could one know he has not already transformed? Xuan comments: 'These four lines describe the unknowable transformations—none of which are within our control.' Are you and I merely dreamers who have yet to awaken? Xuan comments: 'We have not yet attained Mengsun Cai’s surpassing knowledge.'

Moreover, he experienced a startling change in form but suffered no harm to his heart. Though Mengsun Cai’s form underwent shocking alteration, his heart remained unburdened. His dwelling renewed daily, yet he did not truly die. Cheng comments: '旦 means daily renewal. 宅 is the abode of the spirit. The body’s changes are but the daily renewal of this dwelling.' Yao comments: '情 means reality. He knew there was no true death.' Mengsun Cai alone was awake. When others wept, he wept too—this was simply how things were. *乃 means "thus." When others wept, he wept without contrivance.* Su Yu comments: 'The phrase "Mengsun Cai alone was awake" stands alone. We are all dreamers, but Mengsun alone is awake. When others wept, he wept too—this was his spontaneous response.'

Furthermore, people see this temporary body of mine and call it "me." But how can they know what I truly mean by "me"? Is this body truly me, or not? You dream of becoming a bird and soaring to the heavens, *厉 and 戾 are homophones, meaning "to reach."* or of becoming a fish and sinking into the depths. But who can say whether the speaker now is awake or dreaming? Is the bird or fish the dream, or is the one speaking of them the dream? One stumbles upon joy before laughter arises; laughter erupts before one can arrange it. Xuan comments: 'People assume laughter arises from joy, yet when joy suddenly strikes, the heart grasps it before laughter comes. And when laughter bursts forth, it is the spontaneous movement of nature—one cannot contrive or arrange it. Thus, joy and laughter are not under our control.' If you calmly accept the arrangements of transformation, you enter the vast oneness of Heaven. Xuan comments: 'From this, we see that nothing is within our control—there is always something arranging it in the unseen. One should simply accept these arrangements, letting go of sorrow over death and transformation, and thus enter the empty, unified vastness of Heaven.'"
